College of Chemistry & Chemical Engineering Key Laboratory of Chemical Additives for China National Light Industry Shaanxi University of Science & Technology Xi'an 710021 China Selective oxidation of lignin-derived vanillyl alcohol to vanillin is a vital reaction due to the widely application of vanillin. From aspect of green catalysis and sustainability, metal-free based heterogeneous catalyst for the entitled reaction is promising. In the present work, Se doped boron carbonitride (Se-BCN) nanotubes catalyst was rationally prepared and employed as the metal-free catalyst for the entitled reaction. The conversion can achieve 94.4 % with the selectivity of 89.4 % at 120 °C for 4 h, which is higher than most reported metal-based catalytic system. The reasons for the enhanced activity and selectivity of Se doped BCN nanotubes catalyst were revealed from the kinetic investigation and adsorption of vanillyl alcohol and vanillin. Mechanism study reveals that radicals are involved in the entitled reaction. Graphical abstract Image, graphical abstract Keywords Metal-free carbon based catalyst Se doped Selective oxidation Vanillyl alcohol Vanillin Data availability Data will be made available on request. 1 Introduction Selective oxidation reaction with molecular O2 as the oxidant is widely accepted as a green route for preparation value-added chemicals due to that water is a green byproduct. Selective oxidation of alcohol to aldehyde, C(sp3)–OH to CO, is one of the typical oxidation reactions, which has been flourished [1,2]. Vanillyl alcohol (4‑hydroxy-3-methoxybenzyl alcohol), derived from lignin oxidation depolymerization, is often employed as one of the lignin model compounds to mechanistically insight bond cleavage in lignin due to complex polymeric structure of lignin [3,4]. Besides, vanillyl alcohol can be selectively oxidized to vanillin (4‑hydroxy-3-methoxybenzaldehyde) that is widely used in the field of perfume, food additives, and pharmaceutical. Moreover, the market value of vanillin is approximately 7.5 times of vanillyl alcohol, making selective oxidation of lignin-derived vanillyl alcohol to vanillin a compelling techno-economic reaction [5]. Consequently, it is attractive to explore the green catalytic system for selective oxidation of vanillyl alcohol to vanillin. Various heterocatalysts have been explored for the entitled reaction with molecular O2 as an oxidant and excellent catalytic performances have been achieved, which are mainly focused on the metal oxides such as Ag0.5Pd1/ZrO2 [6], Co doped spinel copper ferrite [7], and LaFeO3 perovskite [8], etc. However, metal-based heterocatalyst is inevitably suffered the metal leaching during the oxidation process and may contaminate the product, limiting the application of vanillin. Therefore, it is urgent and desired to develop a metal-free catalytic system with high efficiency (high conversion and selectivity) for the entitled reaction from the aspect of sustainability. Carbon materials such as carbon nanotubes, graphene, and porous carbon are considered as ideal non-metallic catalysts due to their excellent chemical properties, widely usable, and tunable surface properties. Heteroatom doped carbon can redistribute the surface charge, which can significantly enhance the chemisorption of organic substrate and molecular O2 [9–11]. The boron carbonitride (BCN) nanotube has been the research hotspot due to its high specific surface area, conductivity, and enhanced chemisorption of substrate [12,13], providing abundant active sites and enhancing the electron transfer since the reaction nature of redox reaction is electron transferring. In addition, previous study has found that doped Se can enhance the catalytic activity and selectivity of carbon-based metal-free catalyst for the aerobic oxidation [14–16]. Therefore, it is expected that the BCN nanotube and Se doped BCN nanotube exhibit good catalytic performances for the entitled reaction. However, to the best of our knowledge, no report about BCN tube or Se doped BCN tube for selective oxidation of vanillyl alcohol to vanillin with molecular O2 as the oxidant is conducted. Herein, Se doped BCN nanotube catalyst was prepared by the one-pot facile pyrolysis method and was employed as the metal-free catalyst for selective oxidation of vanillyl alcohol to vanillin without base under molecular O2. Thanks to the doped Se, the activity and selectivity are significantly improved on the Se doped BCN catalyst, which is higher than most reported metal-based catalytic system. The reasons for the enhanced activity and selectivity of the Se dope BCN catalyst were revealed by the kinetic and mechanism investigation. Attractively, the present work provides a strategy that Se doped BCN nanotube can synergistically enhance the reaction activity and selectivity of the entitled reaction. 2 Experimental section 2.1 Materials Urea, polyethylene glycol (PEG-2000), and SeO2 were purchased from Shanghai Macklin Biochemical Technology Co., Ltd. Boric acid, vanillyl alcohol, and acetonitrile used for catalyzing the reaction were purchased from Shanghai Titan Technology Co., Ltd. Vanillin and vanillic acid were purchased from Shanghai Aladdin Biochemical Technology Co., Ltd. All chemicals were used as received without further purification or treatment. 2.2 Preparation of nanotube materials A 5.0 g urea, 0.5 g PEG-2000 (polyethylene glycol), 0.15 g boric acid, and 0.0375 g selenium dioxide were dissolved in 50 mL deionized water by stirring vigorously at room temperature to obtain a homogeneous mixed solution. Solid was derived after the above-mentioned solution was evaporated at 80 °C for 24 h, and then was calcined under argon atmosphere at 950 °C for 4 h. The obtained black powder was named as Se-BCN-950. Catalysts with different calcination temperatures were prepared by the identical method with the name Se-BCN-x, where x was the calcination temperature. The other catalysts doped with only selenium or boron were named as Se-CN-950 and BCN-950. Catalyst without Se and B heteroatoms was named as CN-950. 2.3 Catalyst characterization The synthesized catalysts were characterized morphologically using Hitachi S-4800 field emission scanning electron microscope (SEM). The microstructure of the catalysts was observed using a JSM-IT200 transmission electron microscope (TEM). Fourier transform infrared spectroscopy (FT-IR) analysis was carried out on a VECTOR-22 with a resolution of 2 cm−1. X-ray diffraction (XRD) was performed on a model Ultima IV instrument at a scan rate of 10 °/min. X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) was performed on an ESCALAB 250Xi (Thermo Fisher) instrument at 15 kV and 8 mA. N2 adsorption-desorption experiments were carried out using a Micromeritics ASAP 2460 physical adsorption instrument after 12 h of vacuum degassing at 150 °C. The degree of graphitization and disordered structure of the catalyst materials were characterized and analyzed by using a Renishaw-inVia type micro confocal laser Raman spectrometer (Raman). 2.4 Catalytic oxidation of vanillyl alcohol Vanillyl alcohol (0.4 mmol), catalyst (20 mg), and acetonitrile (3.0 mL) were added to an autoclave reactor. The reactor was charged with 1.0 MPa O2 at room temperature. The reaction was carried out at 120 °C for 4 h. After reaction, the autoclave reactor was put into an ice-water bath immediately to quench the reaction. The reacted solution was analyzed by high performance liquid chromatography equipped with an Ultimate XB-C18 column and an ultraviolet detector with a wavelength of 270 nm. The mobile phase was methanol and water (V/V = 2/8) with a flow rate of 1.0 mL/min. The conversion of vanillyl alcohol and the yield of vanillin were calculated using the external standard method. C o n v e r s i o n ( % ) = 1 − n v a n i l l y l a l c o h o l n i n i t i a l v a n i l l y l a l c o h o l × 100 % Y i e l d ( % ) = n v a n i l l i n n i n i t i a l v a n i l l y l a l c o h o l × 100 % 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Characterization of catalysts The morphology of the catalysts was investigated by SEM. CN-950 and Se-CN-950 present a bulk material encapsulated by curled nanosheets (Fig. 1 a and 1c), whereas BCN-950 and Se-BCN-950 show a nano-tubular morphology (Fig. 1b and 1d). TEM images further confirm that CN-950 and Se-CN-950 are nanosheet morphology, while BCN-950 and Se-BCN-950 are nanotube morphology (Fig. 1e and f). This indicates that doped Se has little influence on the morphologies of CN-950 and BCN-950. From the energy dispersive X-ray spectrograms (EDX), it is clear that C, N, and Se are highly homogeneously dispersed (Fig. 1i and l). This indicates that Se is successfully introduced into the BCN nanotubes and the content of Se in Se-BCN-950 is only 0.1 at.% (Fig. 1m). The crystalline structure of the different catalysts was analyzed by XRD (Fig. 2 a). The prepared catalysts show two broad diffraction peaks approximately at 24° and 43°, corresponding to the (002) and (100) crystalline planes of the carbon material [17], respectively. Raman spectroscopy was further used to test the defects and the degree of disorder in the carbon material (Fig. 2b). It can be observed that two typical characteristic peaks appear around 1350 and 1588 cm−1, representing the disordered band (D band) and graphite band (G band), respectively [18,19]. Compared with the CN-950, the doped Se decreases the defects in Se-CN-950. However, the doping of Se enhances the defect of Se-BCN-950, indicating that more defects are induced in the Se-BCN-950 nanotube. In order to study the functional groups of prepared catalysts, they were characterized using FT-IR (Fig. 2c). All the samples show the typical peaks at 1645, 1552, 1465, and 1338 cm−1, which are attributed to the sp2 bonded CN [20], sp2 bonded CN [21], aromatic CC vibration [14], and aromatic CN [22], respectively. For BCN-950 and Se-BCN-950, the peaks at 1388 and 850 cm−1 are caused by the B N in-plane stretching vibration and B-N-B out-of-plane bending vibration. The peaks at 1100–1300 cm−1 are the overlap of BN bands and CN bands [12]. The peak positions in BCN-950 and Se-BCN-950 are identical, indicating that the main structure of them are same and the doping of Se does not change the frame structure of BCN. However, the relative intensity of peak at 1388 cm−1 is weakened, which indicates doped Se modifies the microenvironment of BCN. The texture structure of the catalyst was investigated by N2 adsorption-desorption isotherms (Fig. 2d). All of the prepared catalysts belong to the type IV isotherm with a distinct H3-type hysteresis loop [23], indicating that these series of materials have a mesoporous structure. The specific surface area and pore volume increase after the introduction of Se and B (Table S1), respectively. The specific surface area significantly increases to 331 m2‧g−1 for Se-BCN-950 after the simultaneous introduction of both Se and B into the carbon material. This implies that the introduction of Se and B into carbon materials can effectively promote the formation of pores during the carbonization process, thus substantially increasing the specific surface area of the materials, which to some extent exposes more active sites of the catalysts and thereby improves the catalytic activity [24]. The chemical state of the catalyst was further analyzed by XPS. The existence of O, N, C, B and Se in Se-BCN-950 is confirmed by XPS survey (Fig. 3 a). Three peaks can be mainly decomposed in the C 1 s spectrum (Fig. 3b), aromatic CC at 284.6 eV, CNH at 285.4 eV, and NCN− groups at 288.8–289.1 eV [21,25,26], respectively. Compared with CN-950 and BCN-950, the content of CNH groups increases in Se-CN-950 and Se-BCN-950, indicating that introduction of doped Se can improve the content of CNH groups. For the N1 s (Fig. 3c), the peak for CN-950 and Se-CN-950 can be deconvoluted to three peaks approximately at 398.4, 400.9, and 401–403 eV, which are recognized as the pyridinic N, graphitic N, and NO groups [25,27]. For BCN-950 and Se-BCN-950, the N 1 s peak can be decomposed to three peaks at 398.1, 399.0, and 400.4 eV, corresponding to conjugated BN (overlapped with pyridinic N), CNC, and NH terminal groups [26]. From the N1 s analysis, it can be found that the surface structure of BCN-950 and Se-BCN-950 are similar and the introduction of doped Se can enhance the content of −BN− and reduce the content of CNC (Table S2). For the B 1 s (Fig. 3d), two peaks can be deconvoluted at 190.4 and 191.9 eV for BCN-950, corresponding to NBC and sp2 BN bonds [26]. Introduction of doped Se for BCN nanotube can enhance the content of sp2 BN bond (Table S3). In addition, there is no obvious peak position in the Se 3d spectrum, which is caused by the low Se content on the surface of Se-BCN-950. 3.2 Catalytic properties of different catalysts The catalytic performances of the prepared catalysts for selective oxidation of vanillyl alcohol to vanillin were screened. As shown in Table 1 , the oxidation reaction almost does not occur without the catalyst. With CN-950 as the catalyst, the conversion is 4.3 % with the selectivity of 44.2 %. When Se is doped in the CN-950, the conversion is improved to 11.6 % over Se-CN-950, indicating that introduction of the Se can enhance the activity for the entitled reaction. When the reaction is performed on the BCN-950 nanotube, the conversion is 43.8 % and the selectivity to vanillin is 46.3 %. When the Se is doped in BCN-950, the conversion and selectivity are significantly improved to 94.4 % and 89.4 % over Se-BCN-950, indicating that the introduction of Se to the BCN nanotube can enhance the activity and selectivity. In addition, the calcination temperature is found to affect the activity and selectivity (Table 1, entries 5–7) and the 950 °C is the optimized calcination temperature for preparing Se-BCN catalyst. 3.3 Optimization the reaction conditions With optimized catalyst in hand, the reaction solvents for the selective oxidation of vanillyl alcohol to vanillin was investigated such as p-xylene, N, N-dimethylformamide (DMF), isopropanol, acetonitrile, water, and ethyl acetate (Fig. 4 ). It can be found that the conversion of vanillyl alcohol varies in different solvent, which is usually attributed to the solubility of vanillyl alcohol and polarity of solvent [7,28,29]. Because that the solubility usually follows the rule of “like dissolves like”, implying that the solubility follows the polarity trend of solvent. The conversion of vanillyl alcohol in nonpolar solvent of p-xylene is obviously lower than that of other solvents, which is because that the solubility of vanillyl alcohol is lower than other solvents. However, the polarity and solubility are not the main reason for the change of conversion (Table S4). The change trend of conversion in the polarity solvent is not consistent with the change trend of their polarity. The limited solubility data of vanillyl alcohol obtained by literatures is not consistent with the change trend of conversion. Besides, the molecular oxygen solubility in different solvents is also examined (Table S4). The highest solubility in p-xylene but has lowest conversion, while lowest solubility in H2O but has the highest conversion. This contributes that the effect of solubility of molecular oxygen on the solvent effect is negligible. Therefore, the various activity in the solvent is not only related with the polarity and solubility (when the polarity is very low) but also is related to the nature of the catalyst (when the polarity is higher than some extent). Among above-mentioned solvents, best catalytic performance can be obtained in the acetonitrile. The reaction conditions for selective oxidation of vanillyl alcohol to vanillin are further examined. When the reaction temperature varies in the range of 100 to 140 °C (Fig. 5 a), the conversion increases with the increase of the reaction temperature. The selectivity and yield of vanillin firstly enhances and then decline with highest yield at the threshold of 120 °C. This is because that high temperature can lead the further oxidization of vanillin and formation of oligomers [4,30]. The effect of the catalyst dosage on the catalytic performance is investigated (Fig. 5b). The conversion is improved with the increase of the amount of catalyst, which is due to that more accessible active sites are provided with the catalyst dosage increased. However, excess catalyst can lead to the over oxidation of the vanillin to vanillic acid [31], leading the selectivity to vanillin increases and then decrease with that the highest selectivity achieves at the dosage of 20 mg catalyst. The pressure of gas involved in the reaction often affects the catalytic performance. Consequently, the oxygen pressure for the entitled reaction is studied (Fig. 5c). With the oxygen pressure increase, more oxygen can be dissolved in the reaction solution to involve in the reaction, contributing the conversion enhances. However, higher oxygen pressure can cause the side reaction of over oxidation [28], resulting in the decrease of the selectivity to vanillin. Finally, the change trend of conversion and selectivity with the reaction time was monitored (Fig. 5d). The conversion can reach 100 % after 8 h. The selectivity to vanillin increases in the range of 2 to 4 h but gradually reduces after 4 h, contributing the highest yield of vanillin at 4 h. It is worth to note that the present metal-free catalytic performance is comparable with the metal-based catalysts and the reported metal-free catalyst (Table S5). Moreover, the present metal-free catalyst provides a new approach to enhance the metal-free catalytic performance by doped Se in the carbon-based catalyst. 3.5 The adsorption of vanillyl alcohol and vanillin on the catalyst It is known that the adsorption of the substrate and product can affect the activity and selectivity of the heterogeneous catalysis reaction. The adsorption of vanillyl alcohol and vanillin on different catalysts is investigated under the identical reaction concentration of vanillyl alcohol and dosage of catalyst. The adsorption capacity data after equilibration are listed in Table 2 . Compared with CN-950, both the adsorption of vanillyl alcohol and vanillin decrease on Se-CN-950. However, the adsorption capacity of vanillyl alcohol is improved from 2.1 mmol‧g−1 for BCN-950 to 3.0 mmol‧g−1 for Se-BCN-950, which can enhance the surface concentration of substrate on the catalyst and improve the oxidation rate of vanillyl alcohol on the catalyst surface, contributing the increase of the activity. The adsorption capacity of vanillin significantly decreases from 0.65 mmol‧g−1 for BCN-950 to 0.20 mmol‧g−1 for Se-BCN-950, which can favor desorption and disfavor the over oxidation of the formed vanillin on the catalyst surface, resulting in the improvement of the selectivity to vanillin. 3.6 Catalyst stability and active sites To test the stability of the Se-BCN-950, thermal filtration experiment is conducted. The catalyst was removed after 2 h of reaction and then the reaction mixture without solid catalyst was continued under the identical conditions (Fig. 6 a). It can be found that the yield of vanillin does not change for the further 2 to 4 h after the solid catalyst is removed, indicating the heterogeneous catalysis nature. For the recycle experiment, the solid catalyst was separated after reaction. After the used catalyst was suffered washing with acetonitrile and dried, it was directly used in the next run. It can be found in Fig. 6b that the activity and selectivity gradually decrease during the 5-time recycling of the catalyst. To reveal the reason for this gradually decline of catalytic performances, the one-time used catalyst was characterized. No obvious change is observed from SEM images, the XRD patterns, and Raman spectra for the fresh and used catalyst (Fig. S1 and S2a-2b). But the structure of catalyst may be changed due to that three featured peaks at 1353, 1589, and 3452 cm−1 is observed by FT-IR observations (Fig. S2c). This is because the formation of oxygen-containing CO/CO and OH groups on the carbon-based catalyst during the oxidation process. This is because that the vacancies or “holes” can be generated on the BCN tube and the disorder part can be functionalized under the oxidation reaction conditions [32–34], resulting oxygen-containing (mainly carboxyl and hydroxyl) groups decorated on the surface and these functional groups favor the exfoliation of tubes. This can be verified by the fact that the specific surface area is enhanced from 331 m2‧g−1 for the fresh catalyst to 435 m2‧g−1 for the used catalyst (Table S1 and Fig. S2d). The chemical state of the used catalyst is analyzed by XPS. The N and B contents on the surface of catalyst decline while the O content is improved in the used catalyst (Table S6). In the N1 s spectrum, the content of NH terminal groups are reduced and NO groups appeared. For the B1 s, the content of sp2 BN bonds is significantly reduced after use (Table S3). These are due to the functionalization of the Se-BCN. These observations are consistent with the change of FT-IR spectra and specific surface area. In addition, the enhanced content of oxygen functional groups can improve the solubility of the BCN tube in the polar solvent [33], which may be another reason for the loss of the activity. The active sites on the catalyst is the key for rational designing the catalyst. Therefore, the active sites of the present Se-BCN catalyst is investigated. The conversion on BCN-950 (43.8 %) and Se-BCN-950 (94.4 %) is much higher than that of CN-950 (4.3 %) and the Se-CN-950 (11.6 %). From XPS spectra, it can be found that BCN-950 and Se-BCN-950 possess two new peaks of conjugated BN and −CNC−, indicating that these two groups may contribute to the activity sites. However, the content of these two peaks varies little in the used catalyst (Table S2) but the conversion decreases from 94.4 % to 85.8 % and selectivity declines from 89.4 % to 64.2 %, implying that the −BN− and −CNC− are not the main active sites. The content of sp2 BN bonds at 191.5–191.9 eV are 71.3 %, 85.4 %, and 35.6 % for the BCN-950, Se-BCN-950, and used Se-BCN-950 (Table S3), whose change trend is consistent with the conversion change trend, suggesting that the sp2 BN bonds contributes to the active sites. From above analysis, it can be proposed that the active sites are related with sp2 BN bonds and CNC− bonds. During the oxidation process at reaction condition, the defect carbon atoms are oxidized to the oxygen-containing functional groups, leading the breakage of BN groups and some B and N atoms leached. Therefore, the amount of active sites contributed from B and N atoms decreases which confirmed by the surface content decrease of element B and N from XPS, leading the decline of the activity. On the other hand, the functional groups increase the solubility of Se-BCN-950, leading the partially loss of the catalyst. 3.7 Kinetic and mechanism investigations To further understand the reaction process, the reaction kinetics were investigated. Vanillyl alcohol oxidation is a consecutive reaction including oxidation of vanillyl alcohol to vanillin and further oxidation of vanillin to vanillic acid (Scheme 1 ). The reaction rate constant of each step can be obtained from the kinetic curve for the continuous oxidation reaction [35,36]. As shown in Fig. 7 , a good linear relationship can be obtained by plotting -ln (1-X) against the reaction time (t) with vanillyl alcohol and vanillin as the substrate respectively, indicating that each step of the consecutive reaction is a first-order reaction. The rate constant k 1 for oxidation of vanillyl alcohol to vanillin is 0.4200 h−1 at 120 °C, and the rate constant k 2 for the oxidation of vanillin to vanillic acid is 0.0485 h−1 at 120 °C. Large k 1 can result in the high activity for conversion of vanillyl alcohol. The lower k 2 than k 1 can enhance the selectivity of vanillin. Herein, k 1 is about 10 times of k 2, indicating that the selectivity is kinetically controlled for the present reaction system. With k 1 and k 2 in hand, the maximum yield of vanillin can be calculated according the kinetic equations as well as the corresponding time and conversion [37]. The calculated maximum yield of vanillin is 75.4 % at 120 °C with the corresponding conversion of 91.2 % and selectivity of 82.7 %, which is roughly consistent with the experimental data, indicating the rational kinetic model of the entitled reaction. The apparent activation energies (E a) of the two-step reactions are obtained according to the Arrhenius equation. The E a for the oxidation of vanillyl alcohol to vanillin is 30.3 kJ‧mol−1 (Fig. 7c), which is approximately the same as that documented for the oxidation of vanillyl alcohol with molecular oxygen over metal-based catalyst of graphene oxide-supported Mn3O4 and Ag0.5Pd1/ZrO2 [6,31]. The E a for the oxidation of vanillin to vanillic acid is 52.3 kJ‧mol−1, which contributes to the low k 2 for the kinetic contribution of the high selectivity. To investigate the oxidation reaction mechanism, four free radical scavengers are used to determine the free radicals that may involve in the reaction (Fig. 8 ). The activity decreases slightly when tert‑butanol (t-BuOH) and 2,6-di‑tert‑butyl‑4-methylphenol (BHT) are respectively added in the reaction system. With bromotrichloromethane (CBrCl3) and 2,2,6,6-tetramethylpiperidinyl-1-oxide (TEMPO) added in the catalytic system, the activity changes little. These indicate that •OH and •O2 − involve in the reaction mechanism. Molecular oxygen can be adsorbed with the side mode to the carbon atoms adjacent to N/B/Se atom at the surface of the catalyst, in which the carbon near to B atom can donate more electrons than that of N atom to the 2π* orbit of O2 to weaken the OO bond and form the CO bonds between the catalyst and O2 [11]. In addition, the B dopant itself can also adsorb O2 [9,38]. This is the reason that BCN-950 and Se-BCN-950 have higher conversion than that of CN-950 and Se-CN-950, which is consistent with the above discussion that the actives sites are related to B and N atoms. Consequently, the superoxide radicals of •O2 − generate on the catalyst surface. In addition, the doped Se can improve the electron transfer between the catalyst and O2, favoring the O2 dissociation and further enhancing this •O2 − generation process and activity. Se dopant site can link to •O2 − by donating the electrons to abstract the hydrogen of vanillyl alcohol adsorbed on the catalyst surface to generate vanillin and water [14]. Moreover, this interaction between the Se doped sites and reactive oxygen species (•O2 − and •OH) can confine the radicals on the surface of the catalyst [14,39], decreasing the none-catalysis oxidation of vanillin by radicals, therefore, contributing to the improvement of selectivity to vanillin on Se-CN-950. 4 Conclusion Se doped BCN nanotube is successfully prepared to achieve the metal-free selective oxidation of vanillyl alcohol to vanillin. The conversion is 94.4 % with the selectivity of 89.4 % at 120 °C for 4 h, which is higher than most reported metal-based catalytic system. Doped Se can enhance the adsorption of vanillyl alcohol substrate to enhance the activity and decline the adsorption of vanillin product to improve the selectivity. Kinetic study reveals that vanillyl alcohol is easier to be oxidized than that of vanillin under present catalytic system, which kinetically contributing to the high selectivity. •O2 − and •OH are involved in the reaction and the doped Se can enhance the interaction between catalyst and O2 to activate O2, increasing the activity. The doped Se also can confine the generated radicals on the catalytic surface, decreasing the none-catalytic oxidation of vanillin thus improving the selectivity. This work provides a new approach for exploring metal-free carbon-based catalyst for selective oxidation of alcohol to aldehyde. coredata.dc:description: Selective oxidation of lignin-derived vanillyl alcohol to vanillin is a vital reaction due to the widely application of vanillin. From aspect of green catalysis and sustainability, metal-free based heterogeneous catalyst for the entitled reaction is promising. In the present work, Se doped boron carbonitride (Se-BCN) nanotubes catalyst was rationally prepared and employed as the metal-free catalyst for the entitled reaction. The conversion can achieve 94.4 % with the selectivity of 89.4 % at 120 °C for 4 h, which is higher than most reported metal-based catalytic system. The reasons for the enhanced activity and selectivity of Se doped BCN nanotubes catalyst were revealed from the kinetic investigation and adsorption of vanillyl alcohol and vanillin. Mechanism study reveals that radicals are involved in the entitled reaction.
